der.title: Democracia en red
text: DeR is an NGO founded in 2014, that was born from a diagnosis about the status quo and because fed up of diagnoses and diagnosticians. We were born to build practice, technique and poetry that allow us to imagine and implement innovations in the political system, to open decision processes, to redistribute power.

For us “to influence” means to promote effective changes in the relationship between representatives and represented, a change that enables new governance schemes (more collaborative), new bureaucratic logics (more sensitive) and new public spaces (both digital and territorial).
DemocracyOS is a participation platform that allows citizens to inform, debate and vote on a more quick and easy way.

DemocracyOS is conceived as a versatile, simple and scalable web application for collective decision-making that serves as a tool for citizens interested in improving access to information, civic participation and opening channels of interaction between new power building spaces and the political system: civic activists, civil organizations and government actors.
list: Developed as open source, with more than 50000 users.
Used by over 40 institutions, movements and political parties around the world.
It works on any device with a web browser.

civicStack.text: CivicStack is a repository of open source technologies for citizen participation promoted by organizations that use or develop open (source) technology to improve citizen processes, encourage the opening of information and facilitate online civic behavior.

hechaLaLey.title: Hecha la ley
hechaLaLey.text: Inspired by the idea of bill-tracking, “Hecha la ley” is an open source development that works by calculating the differences in a bill as it progresses in the parliamentary process. Today in the testing stage, it is a tool designed for the specialized press and the professional body (advisors and journalists) of the parliaments.

text: It is necessary to rethink the educational model. Today, children continue to be educated for the industrial society: citizens-consumers who only learn to choose between options and access standardized knowledge, administered vertically and with disciplinary dynamics of “rewards and punishments”.

The Self-Organized Learning Environments (S.O.L.E.) are spaces that at first sight seem somewhat chaotic: many children, some / a few computers and a big question. The proposal organizes group access to computers to investigate and answer a stimulating question. Thus, new interactions arise in the classroom. The magic unleashed by this experience ignites the curiosity and amazement of children, the great engines of this device.

Based on the methodology of Dr. Sugata Mitra, the approach of S.O.L.E. is concluding its pilot application in School No. 20 of the City of Buenos Aires, thanks to an agreement with the Ministry of Education. In total, we conducted more than 160 sessions of S.O.L.E., in 4 stages in 2015 and 2016, in 5 grades of initial education of said School.
Among its results and learning, we highlight the following:
items: In 94% of the sessions, the children were able to construct an appropriate response to the curricular question that was proposed.
In the knowledge retention test carried out at the end of stage 4 (June 2016), the students remembered 80% of the contents worked on in SOLE.
Teachers report improvements in reading comprehension skills, mainly when done in groups.
The evaluation of the ability to acquire knowledge on the Internet (CACI) gave better results, 20% higher than those of schools set up as “control groups”.
From the focus and activities developed, it was possible to impact on the aspirational goals of some students.

text: The crisis of representation is Latin American and, therefore, the debates must also be Latin American. Think of scalable solutions in different countries, learn from local experiences and discuss implementations of the same tools in different socio-economic and institutional contexts.
From Democracia en Red we are committed to this network of people in Latin America who are working, from the political system and / or civil society, on the paradigm of civic innovation.

After the founding meeting of Buenos Aires, in July 2016, we worked together on the development of innovations that allow us to participate in the design of new instances of citizen participation with an impact on the political system.

list.title: As products of the Network we can highlight:
items: The future release of “Recovered Politics” (October 2016), audio-visual material of interviews with members of the Network.

The future release of “What democracy for the XXI Century. volII ”(February 2017), publication of epub format with reflections on new ways for democratic representation and the political subject of the XXI century.

Workshop on “innovative political campaigns” for members of the Ativista Bank (bancadaativista.org), was held in Sao Paulo in August 2016, with 5 members of the Network (Agustín Frizzera, DeR, Arg, Rodrigo Etchecopar, RD, Chi, Caio Tendolini, UpDate, Br, Susana Ochoa and Alejandra Parra, WikiPolítica, Mx) as exhibitors.

clip.title: Latin American connections of Political Innovation
text: The CLIP Initiative aims to create conditions, institutional reforms and a different political culture, from the present and for the medium and long term, that  contribute to improve and transform democracy for an effective redistribution of power.

As part of its Strategic Council, DeR is committed to the CLIP as it seeks to generate knowledge from the theoretical / practical on the dilemmas of sustainable development and the new frameworks for political exercise; articulate experiences and lessons learned among the participants of the initiative; accompany and prepare the actors when they decide to participate in the electoral dispute or join a state public management.
